critique: This document primarily concerns the exercise of executive power during wartime. It authorizes a Major-General to control the police, arrest disloyal persons, declare martial law, and suspend habeas corpus in Baltimore. It also commends military successes. Given the context of the Civil War, the document prioritizes national security and federal authority. There is little to assess regarding immigration, economic regulation, or social inclusion. The ideological tilt is towards preserving the Union, which could be seen as moderately conservative in the context of the time, given that it was resisting what they viewed as an attempt to destroy the country. The expansion of executive power and federalism are notable.
